title: 110_hr6390
content: The "Caregiver Financial Relief Act of 2008" includes a refundable credit for long-term care under the Family Care Credit section. The "Caregiver Financial Relief Act of 2008" offers a tax credit of $3,000 per eligible caregiver for the taxable year, with a limit of 2 individuals (4 for joint returns). The credit is reduced by $100 for each $1,000 of modified adjusted gross income exceeding the threshold amount. The "Caregiver Financial Relief Act of 2008" provides a tax credit of $3,000 per eligible caregiver for the taxable year, with a limit of 2 individuals (4 for joint returns). The credit is reduced by $100 for each $1,000 of modified adjusted gross income exceeding the threshold amount of $150,000 for joint returns, $100,000 for individuals not married, and $75,000 for married individuals filing separately. The term 'applicable individual' refers to an individual certified by a physician as having long-term care needs for at least 180 consecutive days within the taxable year. Individuals with long-term care needs must be certified by a physician as meeting specific requirements, including being at least 6 years old and unable to perform at least 3 activities of daily living without substantial assistance. Individuals with long-term care needs must be certified by a physician as meeting specific requirements, including being at least 6 years old and requiring substantial supervision due to severe cognitive impairment or inability to engage in age-appropriate activities. Individuals aged 2 to 6 with severe psychological disabilities, mental retardation, or related developmental disabilities may require supervision to protect their health and safety, avoiding residence in psychiatric hospitals or similar facilities. The term 'psychological disability' refers to any diagnosable clinical condition on Axis I or Axis II of the current edition of the American Psychiatric Association's guidelines. Individuals under 2 years of age may require specific durable medical equipment or a skilled practitioner if their parents or guardians are absent. The term 'mental retardation' refers to a developmental disability that requires substantial supervision or residence in a specialized facility approved by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Eligible caregivers are defined in the context of providing care for individuals with mental retardation. The Health and Human Services defines eligible caregivers as individuals who can claim a deduction for themselves, their spouse, or dependents under certain tax provisions. An individual may qualify for additional standard deductions under specific tax provisions if certain requirements are met. An individual who is not a qualifying child for the taxable year must meet the residency test by having their principal place of abode at the taxpayer's home for over half the taxable year. The taxpayer's household member for the entire taxable year is considered an eligible caregiver. If multiple individuals are eligible caregivers for the same person in the same calendar year, the taxpayer will be treated as the eligible caregiver if each individual (other than the taxpayer) files a declaration stating they will not claim the person. The eligible caregiver will not claim the individual for the credit if a written declaration is not filed. In the case of married individuals filing separately, the determination of the eligible caregiver will be based on the individual with the highest modified adjusted gross income. The rules require taxpayers to include the name, taxpayer identification number, and physician's identification number on their tax return to claim the credit. The credit is not allowed for periods less than 12 months, except in cases of taxpayer death. The section will not apply to taxable years after December 31, 2010. The tax rules require inclusion of correct TIN or physician identification for claiming the family care credit. Amendments were made to section 6213(g) of the tax code to address omissions of required information on returns. Amendments were made to the tax code, specifically section 36, to update the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. Amendments were made to the tax code, including modifications to the dependent care credit and the addition of a family care credit. The effective date for these changes is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2008. The tax code was amended to include a new provision allowing a tax credit for costs incurred to care for parents and grandparents who do not live with the taxpayer. This provision applies to taxable years beginning in 2009 and 2010. SEC. 4. DEPENDENT CARE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM EXCLUSION LIMITATION TO BE APPLIED WITH RESPECT TO EACH QUALIFYING INDIVIDUAL. Increased exclusion limitation for 2009 and 2010 under section 129 of the Internal Revenue Code allows for up to 4 qualifying individuals per taxpayer. Identifying information is required for these individuals. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2008, regarding dependent care assistance provided to qualifying individuals. The dollar limit on the amount creditable is adjusted accordingly.
